newsitem.title: GREECE: New way out for Greek conscientious objectors.
newsitem.headline: New way out for Greek conscientious objectors.

text.p: The Greek parliament has passed a law offering conscientious objectors an alternative to military service for the first time, parliamentary officials said on Friday.
The 300-seat house passed the law by a majority vote late on Thursday. The estimated 2,500 Greek objectors will serve their time in the public sector.
They will be able to work in public hospitals or municipal services for about double the 19-month regular military service period.
Human rights groups have called the extended period for alternative service for conscientious objectors punitive and called on the government to shorten it.

Military courts often jail conscientious objectors -- about 300 of them are in prison now -- and international human rights groups had strongly criticised the country for providing no alternative to military service.
Most of those in jail are Jehovah's Witnesses who present themselves to military authorities but refuse to bear arms on religious grounds.
Most of the other conscientious objectors are Greeks who simply fail to show up for military service and are dodging authorities.
